channel.title: Morning Trade
channel.description: Delivered every Monday by 10 a.m., Weekly Trade examines the latest news in global trade politics and policy.

item.title: What's next for the USMCA review
item.description: A USTR report outlining its position on whether to extend USMCA for another 16 years is due to Congress by early January, following three days of hearings last week and a meeting Friday between leaders of the three countries.
item.dc:creator: By Doug Palmer

item.title: Trump’s tariffs test GOP patience
item.description: New POLITICO polling data shows Republican support for President Donald Trump’s trade and tariff policies is constrained by cost pressures.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Greer, Lutnick hustle in Brussels
item.description: Both the Trump administration and the European Union argue the other is straying from the spirit of their summer tariff deal as senior officials gather in Belgium.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Rare earths still bedevil US-China talks
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said he hopes the United States and China can finalize the details of their rare earth export agreement by Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Dems, union groups blast Trump's port fee pivot
item.description: The Trump administration is facing scrutiny over its decision to pause port fees on China-linked ships for one year as part of broader trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Will Trump’s China deal help in court?
item.description: President Donald Trump said his emergency tariff regime is necessary after bargaining with China ahead of the Supreme Court hearing on his sweeping actions this week.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Trump clinches deals in Asia as Xi summit looms
item.description: President Donald Trump is touting new deals with China’s neighbors ahead of the much-anticipated sit-down with the Chinese leader Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Trump demurs, China hardens
item.description: President Donald Trump acknowledged limitations to his tariff strategy with China, ahead of a planned meeting with President Xi Jinping aimed at securing a permanent truce.
item.dc:creator: By Ari Hawkins

item.title: Operation De-escalation
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent accused China of making a major trade “miscalculation” last week, but he also said he was “optimistic” the two sides can resolve their disagreement through talks rather than tariffs.
item.dc:creator: By Doug Palmer
